title: Premier League sack race: Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino favourite for the chop
text:
Mauricio Pochettino has emerged as the new favourite to be the next Premier League manager sacked from his position at the helm, following Tottenham's home humiliation at the hands of Bayern Munich.

A grueling week for under-fire managers has seen the intensity crank up tenfold, with Bayern's 7-2 demolition of Spurs upon their own turf now plunging Pochettino into new depths of uncertainty.

Wanted by Real Madrid and Manchester United just six months ago, the Argentine faces being cast aside by the club who were so desperate to retain his services - or so the bookmakers believe with their current reducing odds.

Mauricio Pochettino has emerged as favourite to be the next Premier League manager sacked

Pochettino watched on as his team were torn apart at home by Bayern Munich

Marco Silva is right behind Pochettino in the sack race, with Everton still underperforming

Pochettino stands at 5/2 to receive the chop before any of his peers across the leading bookmakers, with Paddypower, betVictor and Betfair all pricing the same.

Joining Pochettino on the ropes is Newcastle chief Steve Bruce, who is still reeling from a 5-0 mauling at the hands of Brendan Rodgers' high-flying Leicester.

Bruce is 7/2 to be given his marching orders, despite an apparent lack of personnel willing to step up and take on the perceived poisoned chalice that is the Newcastle job.

Steve Bruce's odds of the chop are lowering, following a recent drubbing at Leicester

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has overseen the worst start to a season in 30years with Man United

Marco Silva's struggles at Everton see him just behind Pochettino in the favourite stakes, with only one win in his last five game and the Toffees badly stuttering in 15th place.

Looming over the pack of managerial worriers is Manchester United's Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who has overseen the club's worst start to a season in 30 years.

Now finding his side ravaged by injuries and desperately short in the attacking third, Solskjaer looks like a man constantly wondering where the next win is coming from.

Ladbrokes and William Hill currently have the Norwegian at 6/1 to depart Old Trafford in the coming weeks, with United become greater doubts to make the top four as the weeks tick by.

As Premier League action returns this weekend, Solskjaer goes up against Bruce as United travel to Newcastle for a crunch encounter.

Pochettino's Tottenham will look to get back on track against Brighton, while Silva and Everton face the testing trip of an away visit to Burnley.
